Question 4: What is the name of the movement that Velutha is a part of, which is a countermovement to Indira Gandhi's "Green Revolution"? Options: A. Communist countermovement, B. Green Revolution, C. Socialist movement, D. Environmental movement Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the name of the river that is mentioned in the novel, which was once bursting with life but is now damaged due to the Green Revolution? Options: A. Ayemenem River, B. Kerala River, C. Ganges River, D. Periyar River Correct Option: D
Question 6: According to the novel, what is the name of the "love laws" that forbid intimacy between different castes? Options: A. Caste laws, B. Love laws, C. Social laws, D. Cultural laws Correct Option: B

It symbolizes the fragility of life., C. It highlights the contrast between the natural world and the artificial setting of the church., D. It is a metaphor for the twins' emotional state. Correct Option: C
Question 8: How does the novel portray the impact of the Green Revolution on the people of lower castes? Options: A. It portrays the Green Revolution as a positive development that brought prosperity to the people., B. It highlights the environmental damage caused by the Green Revolution., C. It shows how the Green Revolution forced people from lower castes off their land and caused widespread damage., D. It does not mention the impact of the Green Revolution on the people of lower castes. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the significance of the image of the baby bat crawling up a funeral sari? Options: A. It represents the twins' innocence and vulnerability., B. It symbolizes the cycle of life and death., C. It highlights the contrast between the natural world and the artificial setting of the funeral., D. It is a metaphor for the twins' emotional state. Correct Option: C
Question 10: How does the novel portray the relationship between the individual and the nation in the context of the Green Revolution? Options: A. It portrays the individual as a passive victim of the nation's policies., B. It highlights the individual's agency and resistance to the nation's policies., C. It shows how the individual is shaped by the nation's policies, but also has the power to shape them., D. It does not mention the relationship between the individual and the nation. Correct Option: C

However, if I had to choose the generated MCQ that is closest to the ground truth MCQ in terms of its focus on character interactions, I would select Question 3: "What is the name of the worker in the twins' family's pickle factory who is a member of the 'untouchable' caste?" This question is still quite different from the ground truth MCQ, but it at least involves characters and their relationships, which is the general area of focus for the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After a savage seafaring skirmish and eight long days of being 
battered by waves, Väinämöinen— a powerful bard and 
sage as old as the world itself— washed up on the shores 
of distant Pohjola. Unlike his home Kalevala, Pohjola was 
a dark and frozen land, ruled by Louhi, “the gap-tooth 
hag of the North." The cunning witch nursed Väinämöinen 
back to health but demanded a reward for 
returning him home. Not content with mere gold or silver, Louhi wanted what did not yet exist— 
the Sampo. To be forged from “the tips of white-swan
feathers," “the milk of greatest virtue," “a single grain of barley," and 
“the finest wool of lambskins," this artifact was said to be 
an endless font of wealth. But Väinämöinen knew that 
only Seppo Ilmarinen, the Eternal Hammerer who forged 
the sky-dome itself, could craft such an object. So he convinced Louhi to send him 
home and fetch the smith. Though the journey was far from easy, 
the bard finally made it back to Kalevala. But Ilmarinen refused to go to the gloomy 
North— a land of witches and man-eaters. But keeping true to his word, Väinämöinen tricked Ilmarinen 
into climbing a giant tree, before summoning a mighty storm 
to carry the smith all the way to Pohjola. Ilmarinen was well received in the North. Louhi lavished her guest with 
extravagant hospitality and promised him the hand 
of her beautiful daughter— if he could craft what she wished. When she finally asked if Ilmarinen 
was capable of forging the Sampo, the powerful smith declared he could 
indeed accomplish the task. But try as he might to bend 
the forge to his will, its fires only produced other artifacts— beautiful in appearance but 
ill-mannered in nature. An elegant crossbow that 
thirsted for blood and a gleaming plow that ruined cultivated
fields among others. Finally, Ilmarinen summoned the winds 
themselves to work the bellows, and in three days time he 
pulled the Sampo, with its lid of many colors from 
the forge’s flames. On its sides the smith carefully crafted 
a grain mill, a salt mill, and a money mill. Louhi was so delighted with the object’s 
limitless productive power that she ran off to lock her treasure 
inside a mountain. But when Ilmarinen tried to 
claim his prize, the promised maiden refused to marry him,
and the smith had to return home alone. Years passed, and while 
Pohjola prospered, Ilmarinen and Väinämöinen were without 
wives or great wealth. Bitter about this injustice, the bard 
proposed a quest to retrieve the Sampo, and the two sailed north with the 
help of Lemminkäinen— a beautiful young man with a history 
of starting trouble. Upon arrival, Väinämöinen requested half 
the Sampo’s profits as compensation— or they’d take the artifact by force. Outraged at this request, Louhi summoned 
her forces to fight the heroes. But as her army readied for war, 
the bard played his magic harp, Kantele, entrancing all who heard it and sending 
Pohjola into a deep slumber. Unimpeded, the three men took the Sampo 
and quietly made their escape. Lemminkäinen was ecstatic 
at their success, and demanded that Väinämöinen sing 
of their triumph. The bard refused, knowing the dangers 
of celebrating too early. But after three days of traveling, 
Lemminkäinen’s excitement overwhelmed him, and he recklessly broke out in song. His awful singing voice woke 
a nearby crane, whose screeching cries roused 
the Pohjolan horde. The army made chase. As their warship closed in, Väinämöinen 
raised a rock to breach their hull. Undeterred, Louhi transformed 
into a giant eagle, carrying her army on her back as they 
attacked the heroes’ vessel. She managed to grab the Sampo 
in her claw, but just as quickly, it dropped into 
the sea, shattering into pieces and sinking deep beyond her talon’s reach. Buried on the ocean floor, the remnants of this powerful device 
remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas 
to this very day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Väinämöinen’s home is located in
Options: A. Pohjola, B. Kalevala, C. The North
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the powerful bard and sage that washed up on the shores of Pohjola after a long seafaring skirmish? Options: A. Väinämöinen, B. Louhi, C. Seppo Ilmarinen, D. Lemminkäinen Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the name of the artifact that Louhi wanted Väinämöinen to bring back from Kalevala, which was said to be an endless font of wealth? Options: A. The Sampo, B. The Kantele, C. The Eternal Hammer, D. The Sky-Dome Correct Option: A
Question 3: Who was the Eternal Hammerer that forged the sky-dome itself and was tasked with crafting the Sampo? Options: A. Seppo Ilmarinen, B. Väinämöinen, C. Louhi, D. Lemminkäinen Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the problem that Seppo Ilmarinen faced when trying to forge the Sampo, despite his immense power as a smith? Options: A. He was unable to work the forge due to the cold temperature, B. He was unable to work the bellows, C. The forge's fires only produced other artifacts that were beautiful but ill-mannered in nature, D. He was unable to find the necessary materials Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the final solution that Seppo Ilmarinen came up with to successfully forge the Sampo? Options: A. He used a different type of metal, B. He worked the bellows himself, C. He summoned the winds to work the bellows, D. He used magic Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the outcome of Seppo Ilmarinen's attempt to claim the Sampo as his prize, after it was completed? Options: A. He was able to take the Sampo and return home with great wealth, B. He was able to marry the promised maiden, C. He had to return home alone, D. He was able to keep the Sampo for himself Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the reason behind Väinämöinen's proposal for a quest to retrieve the Sampo, after years of being without a wife or great wealth? Options: A. He wanted to prove his worth as a hero, B. He wanted to get back the Sampo for himself, C. He wanted to right the injustice that had been done to him and Seppo Ilmarinen, D. He wanted to explore the world Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the outcome of the heroes' attempt to take the Sampo by force, after Väinämöinen requested half of the profits as compensation? Options: A. They were successful in taking the Sampo and escaping, B. They were defeated by Louhi's army, C. The Sampo was destroyed and its remains were lost at sea, D. The heroes were able to negotiate with Louhi and retrieve the Sampo peacefully Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the reason behind Lemminkäinen's excitement and decision to break out in song, after three days of traveling with the heroes? Options: A. He was happy to be on the quest and felt a sense of camaraderie with the other heroes, B. He was excited to finally see the Sampo and retrieve it, C. He was overwhelmed by the thrill of adventure and the possibility of wealth and fame, D. He was tired and needed a break Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the final outcome of the heroes' quest to retrieve the Sampo, after Lemminkäinen's singing woke up the Pohjolan horde and they were chased by Louhi's army? Options: A. The heroes were able to take the Sampo and return home with great wealth, B. The Sampo was destroyed and its remains were lost at sea, C. The heroes were defeated by Louhi's army and had to retreat, D. The heroes were able to negotiate with Louhi and retrieve the Sampo peacefully Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, based on the overall intent and context, I would say that Question 1 is the most similar generated MCQ.

Although Question 1 does not directly ask about Väinämöinen's home, it does mention Väinämöinen as the powerful bard and sage that washed up on the shores of Pohjola, which implies that Pohjola is not his home. This is related to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about Väinämöinen's home location.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After a savage seafaring skirmish and eight long days of being 
battered by waves, Väinämöinen— a powerful bard and 
sage as old as the world itself— washed up on the shores 
of distant Pohjola. Unlike his home Kalevala, Pohjola was 
a dark and frozen land, ruled by Louhi, “the gap-tooth 
hag of the North." The cunning witch nursed Väinämöinen 
back to health but demanded a reward for 
returning him home. Not content with mere gold or silver, Louhi wanted what did not yet exist— 
the Sampo. To be forged from “the tips of white-swan
feathers," “the milk of greatest virtue," “a single grain of barley," and 
“the finest wool of lambskins," this artifact was said to be 
an endless font of wealth. But Väinämöinen knew that 
only Seppo Ilmarinen, the Eternal Hammerer who forged 
the sky-dome itself, could craft such an object. So he convinced Louhi to send him 
home and fetch the smith. Though the journey was far from easy, 
the bard finally made it back to Kalevala. But Ilmarinen refused to go to the gloomy 
North— a land of witches and man-eaters. But keeping true to his word, Väinämöinen tricked Ilmarinen 
into climbing a giant tree, before summoning a mighty storm 
to carry the smith all the way to Pohjola. Ilmarinen was well received in the North. Louhi lavished her guest with 
extravagant hospitality and promised him the hand 
of her beautiful daughter— if he could craft what she wished. When she finally asked if Ilmarinen 
was capable of forging the Sampo, the powerful smith declared he could 
indeed accomplish the task. But try as he might to bend 
the forge to his will, its fires only produced other artifacts— beautiful in appearance but 
ill-mannered in nature. An elegant crossbow that 
thirsted for blood and a gleaming plow that ruined cultivated
fields among others. Finally, Ilmarinen summoned the winds 
themselves to work the bellows, and in three days time he 
pulled the Sampo, with its lid of many colors from 
the forge’s flames. On its sides the smith carefully crafted 
a grain mill, a salt mill, and a money mill. Louhi was so delighted with the object’s 
limitless productive power that she ran off to lock her treasure 
inside a mountain. But when Ilmarinen tried to 
claim his prize, the promised maiden refused to marry him,
and the smith had to return home alone. Years passed, and while 
Pohjola prospered, Ilmarinen and Väinämöinen were without 
wives or great wealth. Bitter about this injustice, the bard 
proposed a quest to retrieve the Sampo, and the two sailed north with the 
help of Lemminkäinen— a beautiful young man with a history 
of starting trouble. Upon arrival, Väinämöinen requested half 
the Sampo’s profits as compensation— or they’d take the artifact by force. Outraged at this request, Louhi summoned 
her forces to fight the heroes. But as her army readied for war, 
the bard played his magic harp, Kantele, entrancing all who heard it and sending 
Pohjola into a deep slumber. Unimpeded, the three men took the Sampo 
and quietly made their escape. Lemminkäinen was ecstatic 
at their success, and demanded that Väinämöinen sing 
of their triumph. The bard refused, knowing the dangers 
of celebrating too early. But after three days of traveling, 
Lemminkäinen’s excitement overwhelmed him, and he recklessly broke out in song. His awful singing voice woke 
a nearby crane, whose screeching cries roused 
the Pohjolan horde. The army made chase. As their warship closed in, Väinämöinen 
raised a rock to breach their hull. Undeterred, Louhi transformed 
into a giant eagle, carrying her army on her back as they 
attacked the heroes’ vessel. She managed to grab the Sampo 
in her claw, but just as quickly, it dropped into 
the sea, shattering into pieces and sinking deep beyond her talon’s reach. Buried on the ocean floor, the remnants of this powerful device 
remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas 
to this very day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does Louhi promise to Ilmarinen for crafting the Sampo?
Options: A. Her daughter’s hand, B. A party with extravagant hospitality, C. A new boat
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the powerful bard and sage that washed up on the shores of Pohjola after a long seafaring skirmish? Options: A. Väinämöinen, B. Louhi, C. Seppo Ilmarinen, D. Lemminkäinen Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the name of the artifact that Louhi wanted Väinämöinen to bring back from Kalevala, which was said to be an endless font of wealth? Options: A. The Sampo, B. The Kantele, C. The Eternal Hammer, D. The Sky-Dome Correct Option: A
Question 3: Who was the Eternal Hammerer that forged the sky-dome itself and was tasked with crafting the Sampo? Options: A. Seppo Ilmarinen, B. Väinämöinen, C. Louhi, D. Lemminkäinen Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the problem that Seppo Ilmarinen faced when trying to forge the Sampo, despite his immense power as a smith? Options: A. He was unable to work the forge due to the cold temperature, B. He was unable to work the bellows, C. The forge's fires only produced other artifacts that were beautiful but ill-mannered in nature, D. He was unable to find the necessary materials Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the final solution that Seppo Ilmarinen came up with to successfully forge the Sampo? Options: A. He used a different type of metal, B. He worked the bellows himself, C. He summoned the winds to work the bellows, D. He used magic Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the outcome of Seppo Ilmarinen's attempt to claim the Sampo as his prize, after it was completed? Options: A. He was able to take the Sampo and return home with great wealth, B. He was able to marry the promised maiden, C. He had to return home alone, D. He was able to keep the Sampo for himself Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the reason behind Väinämöinen's proposal for a quest to retrieve the Sampo, after years of being without a wife or great wealth? Options: A. He wanted to prove his worth as a hero, B. He wanted to get back the Sampo for himself, C. He wanted to right the injustice that had been done to him and Seppo Ilmarinen, D. He wanted to explore the world Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the outcome of the heroes' attempt to take the Sampo by force, after Väinämöinen requested half of the profits as compensation? Options: A. They were successful in taking the Sampo and escaping, B. They were defeated by Louhi's army, C. The Sampo was destroyed and its remains were lost at sea, D. The heroes were able to negotiate with Louhi and retrieve the Sampo peacefully Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the reason behind Lemminkäinen's excitement and decision to break out in song, after three days of traveling with the heroes? Options: A. He was happy to be on the quest and felt a sense of camaraderie with the other heroes, B. He was excited to finally see the Sampo and retrieve it, C. He was overwhelmed by the thrill of adventure and the possibility of wealth and fame, D. He was tired and needed a break Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the final outcome of the heroes' quest to retrieve the Sampo, after Lemminkäinen's singing woke up the Pohjolan horde and they were chased by Louhi's army? Options: A. The heroes were able to take the Sampo and return home with great wealth, B. The Sampo was destroyed and its remains were lost at sea, C. The heroes were defeated by Louhi's army and had to retreat, D. The heroes were able to negotiate with Louhi and retrieve the Sampo peacefully Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After a savage seafaring skirmish and eight long days of being 
battered by waves, Väinämöinen— a powerful bard and 
sage as old as the world itself— washed up on the shores 
of distant Pohjola. Unlike his home Kalevala, Pohjola was 
a dark and frozen land, ruled by Louhi, “the gap-tooth 
hag of the North." The cunning witch nursed Väinämöinen 
back to health but demanded a reward for 
returning him home. Not content with mere gold or silver, Louhi wanted what did not yet exist— 
the Sampo. To be forged from “the tips of white-swan
feathers," “the milk of greatest virtue," “a single grain of barley," and 
“the finest wool of lambskins," this artifact was said to be 
an endless font of wealth. But Väinämöinen knew that 
only Seppo Ilmarinen, the Eternal Hammerer who forged 
the sky-dome itself, could craft such an object. So he convinced Louhi to send him 
home and fetch the smith. Though the journey was far from easy, 
the bard finally made it back to Kalevala. But Ilmarinen refused to go to the gloomy 
North— a land of witches and man-eaters. But keeping true to his word, Väinämöinen tricked Ilmarinen 
into climbing a giant tree, before summoning a mighty storm 
to carry the smith all the way to Pohjola. Ilmarinen was well received in the North. Louhi lavished her guest with 
extravagant hospitality and promised him the hand 
of her beautiful daughter— if he could craft what she wished. When she finally asked if Ilmarinen 
was capable of forging the Sampo, the powerful smith declared he could 
indeed accomplish the task. But try as he might to bend 
the forge to his will, its fires only produced other artifacts— beautiful in appearance but 
ill-mannered in nature. An elegant crossbow that 
thirsted for blood and a gleaming plow that ruined cultivated
fields among others. Finally, Ilmarinen summoned the winds 
themselves to work the bellows, and in three days time he 
pulled the Sampo, with its lid of many colors from 
the forge’s flames. On its sides the smith carefully crafted 
a grain mill, a salt mill, and a money mill. Louhi was so delighted with the object’s 
limitless productive power that she ran off to lock her treasure 
inside a mountain. But when Ilmarinen tried to 
claim his prize, the promised maiden refused to marry him,
and the smith had to return home alone. Years passed, and while 
Pohjola prospered, Ilmarinen and Väinämöinen were without 
wives or great wealth. Bitter about this injustice, the bard 
proposed a quest to retrieve the Sampo, and the two sailed north with the 
help of Lemminkäinen— a beautiful young man with a history 
of starting trouble. Upon arrival, Väinämöinen requested half 
the Sampo’s profits as compensation— or they’d take the artifact by force. Outraged at this request, Louhi summoned 
her forces to fight the heroes. But as her army readied for war, 
the bard played his magic harp, Kantele, entrancing all who heard it and sending 
Pohjola into a deep slumber. Unimpeded, the three men took the Sampo 
and quietly made their escape. Lemminkäinen was ecstatic 
at their success, and demanded that Väinämöinen sing 
of their triumph. The bard refused, knowing the dangers 
of celebrating too early. But after three days of traveling, 
Lemminkäinen’s excitement overwhelmed him, and he recklessly broke out in song. His awful singing voice woke 
a nearby crane, whose screeching cries roused 
the Pohjolan horde. The army made chase. As their warship closed in, Väinämöinen 
raised a rock to breach their hull. Undeterred, Louhi transformed 
into a giant eagle, carrying her army on her back as they 
attacked the heroes’ vessel. She managed to grab the Sampo 
in her claw, but just as quickly, it dropped into 
the sea, shattering into pieces and sinking deep beyond her talon’s reach. Buried on the ocean floor, the remnants of this powerful device 
remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas 
to this very day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where does Louhi hide the Sampo?
Options: A. In the depth of the ocean, B. Under her house, C. In Kalevala, D. Inside a mountain
Correct Option: D

The heroes were defeated by Louhi's army and had to retreat, D. The heroes were able to negotiate with Louhi and retrieve the Sampo peacefully Correct Option: B

remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas 
to this very day.

Question: How does Väinämöinen make Louhi’s army fall asleep?
Options: A. by swinging his magic wand, B. by blowing magic powder on them, C. by playing his magic kantele
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After a savage seafaring skirmish and eight long days of being 
battered by waves, Väinämöinen— a powerful bard and 
sage as old as the world itself— washed up on the shores 
of distant Pohjola. Unlike his home Kalevala, Pohjola was 
a dark and frozen land, ruled by Louhi, “the gap-tooth 
hag of the North." The cunning witch nursed Väinämöinen 
back to health but demanded a reward for 
returning him home. Not content with mere gold or silver, Louhi wanted what did not yet exist— 
the Sampo. To be forged from “the tips of white-swan
feathers," “the milk of greatest virtue," “a single grain of barley," and 
“the finest wool of lambskins," this artifact was said to be 
an endless font of wealth. But Väinämöinen knew that 
only Seppo Ilmarinen, the Eternal Hammerer who forged 
the sky-dome itself, could craft such an object. So he convinced Louhi to send him 
home and fetch the smith. Though the journey was far from easy, 
the bard finally made it back to Kalevala. But Ilmarinen refused to go to the gloomy 
North— a land of witches and man-eaters. But keeping true to his word, Väinämöinen tricked Ilmarinen 
into climbing a giant tree, before summoning a mighty storm 
to carry the smith all the way to Pohjola. Ilmarinen was well received in the North. Louhi lavished her guest with 
extravagant hospitality and promised him the hand 
of her beautiful daughter— if he could craft what she wished. When she finally asked if Ilmarinen 
was capable of forging the Sampo, the powerful smith declared he could 
indeed accomplish the task. But try as he might to bend 
the forge to his will, its fires only produced other artifacts— beautiful in appearance but 
ill-mannered in nature. An elegant crossbow that 
thirsted for blood and a gleaming plow that ruined cultivated
fields among others. Finally, Ilmarinen summoned the winds 
themselves to work the bellows, and in three days time he 
pulled the Sampo, with its lid of many colors from 
the forge’s flames. On its sides the smith carefully crafted 
a grain mill, a salt mill, and a money mill. Louhi was so delighted with the object’s 
limitless productive power that she ran off to lock her treasure 
inside a mountain. But when Ilmarinen tried to 
claim his prize, the promised maiden refused to marry him,
and the smith had to return home alone. Years passed, and while 
Pohjola prospered, Ilmarinen and Väinämöinen were without 
wives or great wealth. Bitter about this injustice, the bard 
proposed a quest to retrieve the Sampo, and the two sailed north with the 
help of Lemminkäinen— a beautiful young man with a history 
of starting trouble. Upon arrival, Väinämöinen requested half 
the Sampo’s profits as compensation— or they’d take the artifact by force. Outraged at this request, Louhi summoned 
her forces to fight the heroes. But as her army readied for war, 
the bard played his magic harp, Kantele, entrancing all who heard it and sending 
Pohjola into a deep slumber. Unimpeded, the three men took the Sampo 
and quietly made their escape. Lemminkäinen was ecstatic 
at their success, and demanded that Väinämöinen sing 
of their triumph. The bard refused, knowing the dangers 
of celebrating too early. But after three days of traveling, 
Lemminkäinen’s excitement overwhelmed him, and he recklessly broke out in song. His awful singing voice woke 
a nearby crane, whose screeching cries roused 
the Pohjolan horde. The army made chase. As their warship closed in, Väinämöinen 
raised a rock to breach their hull. Undeterred, Louhi transformed 
into a giant eagle, carrying her army on her back as they 
attacked the heroes’ vessel. She managed to grab the Sampo 
in her claw, but just as quickly, it dropped into 
the sea, shattering into pieces and sinking deep beyond her talon’s reach. Buried on the ocean floor, the remnants of this powerful device 
remain in the realm of Ahti, god of water— where they grind salt for the seas 
to this very day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: While trying to retrieve the Sampo, Louhi transforms into
Options: A. a dragon, B. a giant eagle, C. a monstrous seal
Correct Option: B

Question 2: What was the name of the artifact that Louhi wanted Väinämöinen to bring back from Kalevala, which was said to be an endless font of wealth? Options: A. The Sampo, B. The Kantele, C. The Eternal Hammer, D. The Sky-Dome Correct Option: A
Question 3: Who was the Eternal Hammerer that forged the sky-dome itself and was tasked with crafting the Sampo? Options: A. Seppo Ilmarinen, B. Väinämöinen, C. Louhi, D. Lemminkäinen Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the problem that Seppo Ilmarinen faced when trying to forge the Sampo, despite his immense power as a smith? Options: A. He was unable to work the forge due to the cold temperature, B. He was unable to work the bellows, C. The forge's fires only produced other artifacts that were beautiful but ill-mannered in nature, D. He was unable to find the necessary materials Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the final solution that Seppo Ilmarinen came up with to successfully forge the Sampo? Options: A. He used a different type of metal, B. He worked the bellows himself, C. He summoned the winds to work the bellows, D. He used magic Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the outcome of Seppo Ilmarinen's attempt to claim the Sampo as his prize, after it was completed? Options: A. He was able to take the Sampo and return home with great wealth, B. He was able to marry the promised maiden, C. He had to return home alone, D. He was able to keep the Sampo for himself Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the reason behind Väinämöinen's proposal for a quest to retrieve the Sampo, after years of being without a wife or great wealth? Options: A. He wanted to prove his worth as a hero, B. He wanted to get back the Sampo for himself, C. He wanted to right the injustice that had been done to him and Seppo Ilmarinen, D. He wanted to explore the world Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the outcome of the heroes' attempt to take the Sampo by force, after Väinämöinen requested half of the profits as compensation? Options: A. They were successful in taking the Sampo and escaping, B. They were defeated by Louhi's army, C. The Sampo was destroyed and its remains were lost at sea, D. The heroes were able to negotiate with Louhi and retrieve the Sampo peacefully Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the reason behind Lemminkäinen's excitement and decision to break out in song, after three days of traveling with the heroes? Options: A. He was happy to be on the quest and felt a sense of camaraderie with the other heroes, B. He was excited to finally see the Sampo and retrieve it, C. He was overwhelmed by the thrill of adventure and the possibility of wealth and fame, D. He was tired and needed a break Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the final outcome of the heroes' quest to retrieve the Sampo, after Lemminkäinen's singing woke up the Pohjolan horde and they were chased by Louhi's army? Options: A. The heroes were able to take the Sampo and return home with great wealth, B. The Sampo was destroyed and its remains were lost at sea, C. The heroes were defeated by Louhi's army and had to retreat, D. The heroes were able to negotiate with Louhi and retrieve the Sampo peacefully Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When the Hoover Dam was 
completed in 1936, it created a huge source of 
hydroelectric power and zapped a sleepy desert town to life: 
Las Vegas, Nevada. With the power supply from the dam, Las Vegas soon exploded 
with vibrant displays. The source of these dazzling lights was 
electrified neon gas. There are two tricky obstacles 
to making lighted signs out of this naturally clear, 
odorless gas: capturing it and making it glow. French inventor Georges Claude came up 
with techniques to do both. In 1902, he developed a way of liquefying and 
separating specific gases from the air, producing neon on an industrial 
scale for the first time. By 1910, he had come up with a way 
to trap the gas in a glass tube with a special electrode at either end, 
and neon lighting was born. In workshops like Claude's, artisans known as tube-benders 
made neon signs by hand. The tube-benders heated small sections 
of a long, hollow glass tube and quickly bent them into shape. After the glass cooled, they attached 
electrodes to each end and removed the air with a vacuum pump. Then, they passed a high voltage 
current through the tube to remove any impurities on the 
inside of the glass. Finally, they pumped the neon gas in 
and sealed off the electrodes. When a neon sign is turned on, the electric current causes some of 
the neon atoms' electrons to accelerate and break free of their orbits, leaving 
behind positively charged ions. As these free electrons rush from 
one electrode to the other, they collide with more neon atoms, 
causing them to ionize as well. When these excited electrons fall back 
to their normal energy levels, their excess energy is carried away 
by photons, or particles of light. All this happens in an instant, and the glow from the photons is what 
we see when we switch on a neon sign. Though it's common to call any 
gas-filled sign a "neon" sign, there are actually 5 different 
gases used in production. Each gas emits photons of a different 
wavelength when electrified, which correspond to different 
colors of light. Neon gives off an orange-red glow, argon 
glows a pale lavender, helium a dusty pink, krypton a silver-
white, and xenon a light purple. These 5 gases can be combined 
with color-coated tubing to create an electrified rainbow of 
text and images. Business owners soon realized how 
effective these colorful beacons were for attracting customers. And unlike a light bulb, a neon sign has 
no incandescent filaments to burn out, and can shine continuously for 40 years 
before the gas depletes. By the 1930s, neon signs were lighting 
up storefronts all over the world. Because of the glass tubes' 
fragile nature, it usually wasn't feasible to ship 
them over long distances. Instead, most neon signs were created by 
local neon shops and then installed nearby. Signs with humor, personality, and 
intricate designs proliferated, no two exactly alike. But by the end of World War II, plastics had become widely 
available and inexpensive, and plastic signs supplanted neon 
as messengers of modernity. Many towns removed neon signs they 
viewed as old-fashioned. Today, neon sign production is only 
a fraction of what it was at its peak, but the craft of tube bending lives 
on relatively unchanged. New creations hand-crafted 
by local artisans join survivors from the heyday of neon, hiding in plain sight in city streets 
around the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Neon lighting was first commercially produced in which country?
Options: A. Italy, B. United States, C. France, D. England
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is credited with developing techniques to capture and make neon gas glow? Options: A. Thomas Edison, B. Georges Claude, C. Nikola Tesla, D. Albert Einstein Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary obstacle to making lighted signs out of neon gas? Options: A. Capturing the gas, B. Making the gas glow, C. Both capturing and making the gas glow, D. None of the above Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the process of removing impurities from the inside of a glass tube called? Options: A. Liquefying, B. Separating, C. Ionizing, D. Pumping Correct Option: D
Question 4: What happens when a neon sign is turned on? Options: A. The glass tube breaks, B. The neon atoms' electrons accelerate and break free of their orbits, C. The sign turns off, D. The sign remains unchanged Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the primary difference between a neon sign and a light bulb? Options: A. The color of the light, B. The type of gas used, C. The lifespan of the sign, D. The incandescent filaments used Correct Option: D
Question 6: What happened to neon sign production after the 1930s? Options: A. It increased significantly, B. It remained the same, C. It decreased significantly, D. It became obsolete Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the primary reason why neon signs were not feasible to ship over long distances? Options: A. The gas used was too expensive, B. The glass tubes were too fragile, C. The signs were too heavy, D. The signs were too large Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the craft of tube bending? Options: A. The process of creating neon signs, B. The process of removing impurities from glass tubes, C. The process of shipping neon signs, D. The process of creating intricate designs for neon signs Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the primary advantage of using neon signs over other types of signs? Options: A. They are more energy-efficient, B. They are more durable, C. They can shine continuously for 40 years, D. They are more expensive Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the significance of neon signs in modern society? Options: A. They are a relic of the past, B. They are a symbol of modernity, C. They are a form of art, D. They are a form of entertainment Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 1 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the country where neon lighting was first commercially produced, and the correct answer is France. Question 1 asks about the person who developed techniques to capture and make neon gas glow, and the correct answer is Georges Claude, a French inventor. While the questions are not identical, they both relate to the origins of neon lighting and the role of France/French inventors in its development.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When the Hoover Dam was 
completed in 1936, it created a huge source of 
hydroelectric power and zapped a sleepy desert town to life: 
Las Vegas, Nevada. With the power supply from the dam, Las Vegas soon exploded 
with vibrant displays. The source of these dazzling lights was 
electrified neon gas. There are two tricky obstacles 
to making lighted signs out of this naturally clear, 
odorless gas: capturing it and making it glow. French inventor Georges Claude came up 
with techniques to do both. In 1902, he developed a way of liquefying and 
separating specific gases from the air, producing neon on an industrial 
scale for the first time. By 1910, he had come up with a way 
to trap the gas in a glass tube with a special electrode at either end, 
and neon lighting was born. In workshops like Claude's, artisans known as tube-benders 
made neon signs by hand. The tube-benders heated small sections 
of a long, hollow glass tube and quickly bent them into shape. After the glass cooled, they attached 
electrodes to each end and removed the air with a vacuum pump. Then, they passed a high voltage 
current through the tube to remove any impurities on the 
inside of the glass. Finally, they pumped the neon gas in 
and sealed off the electrodes. When a neon sign is turned on, the electric current causes some of 
the neon atoms' electrons to accelerate and break free of their orbits, leaving 
behind positively charged ions. As these free electrons rush from 
one electrode to the other, they collide with more neon atoms, 
causing them to ionize as well. When these excited electrons fall back 
to their normal energy levels, their excess energy is carried away 
by photons, or particles of light. All this happens in an instant, and the glow from the photons is what 
we see when we switch on a neon sign. Though it's common to call any 
gas-filled sign a "neon" sign, there are actually 5 different 
gases used in production. Each gas emits photons of a different 
wavelength when electrified, which correspond to different 
colors of light. Neon gives off an orange-red glow, argon 
glows a pale lavender, helium a dusty pink, krypton a silver-
white, and xenon a light purple. These 5 gases can be combined 
with color-coated tubing to create an electrified rainbow of 
text and images. Business owners soon realized how 
effective these colorful beacons were for attracting customers. And unlike a light bulb, a neon sign has 
no incandescent filaments to burn out, and can shine continuously for 40 years 
before the gas depletes. By the 1930s, neon signs were lighting 
up storefronts all over the world. Because of the glass tubes' 
fragile nature, it usually wasn't feasible to ship 
them over long distances. Instead, most neon signs were created by 
local neon shops and then installed nearby. Signs with humor, personality, and 
intricate designs proliferated, no two exactly alike. But by the end of World War II, plastics had become widely 
available and inexpensive, and plastic signs supplanted neon 
as messengers of modernity. Many towns removed neon signs they 
viewed as old-fashioned. Today, neon sign production is only 
a fraction of what it was at its peak, but the craft of tube bending lives 
on relatively unchanged. New creations hand-crafted 
by local artisans join survivors from the heyday of neon, hiding in plain sight in city streets 
around the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. photons, B. molecules, C. gamma rays, D. x-rays
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
When the Hoover Dam was 
completed in 1936, it created a huge source of 
hydroelectric power and zapped a sleepy desert town to life: 
Las Vegas, Nevada. With the power supply from the dam, Las Vegas soon exploded 
with vibrant displays. The source of these dazzling lights was 
electrified neon gas. There are two tricky obstacles 
to making lighted signs out of this naturally clear, 
odorless gas: capturing it and making it glow. French inventor Georges Claude came up 
with techniques to do both. In 1902, he developed a way of liquefying and 
separating specific gases from the air, producing neon on an industrial 
scale for the first time. By 1910, he had come up with a way 
to trap the gas in a glass tube with a special electrode at either end, 
and neon lighting was born. In workshops like Claude's, artisans known as tube-benders 
made neon signs by hand. The tube-benders heated small sections 
of a long, hollow glass tube and quickly bent them into shape. After the glass cooled, they attached

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When the Hoover Dam was 
completed in 1936, it created a huge source of 
hydroelectric power and zapped a sleepy desert town to life: 
Las Vegas, Nevada. With the power supply from the dam, Las Vegas soon exploded 
with vibrant displays. The source of these dazzling lights was 
electrified neon gas. There are two tricky obstacles 
to making lighted signs out of this naturally clear, 
odorless gas: capturing it and making it glow. French inventor Georges Claude came up 
with techniques to do both. In 1902, he developed a way of liquefying and 
separating specific gases from the air, producing neon on an industrial 
scale for the first time. By 1910, he had come up with a way 
to trap the gas in a glass tube with a special electrode at either end, 
and neon lighting was born. In workshops like Claude's, artisans known as tube-benders 
made neon signs by hand. The tube-benders heated small sections 
of a long, hollow glass tube and quickly bent them into shape. After the glass cooled, they attached 
electrodes to each end and removed the air with a vacuum pump. Then, they passed a high voltage 
current through the tube to remove any impurities on the 
inside of the glass. Finally, they pumped the neon gas in 
and sealed off the electrodes. When a neon sign is turned on, the electric current causes some of 
the neon atoms' electrons to accelerate and break free of their orbits, leaving 
behind positively charged ions. As these free electrons rush from 
one electrode to the other, they collide with more neon atoms, 
causing them to ionize as well. When these excited electrons fall back 
to their normal energy levels, their excess energy is carried away 
by photons, or particles of light. All this happens in an instant, and the glow from the photons is what 
we see when we switch on a neon sign. Though it's common to call any 
gas-filled sign a "neon" sign, there are actually 5 different 
gases used in production. Each gas emits photons of a different 
wavelength when electrified, which correspond to different 
colors of light. Neon gives off an orange-red glow, argon 
glows a pale lavender, helium a dusty pink, krypton a silver-
white, and xenon a light purple. These 5 gases can be combined 
with color-coated tubing to create an electrified rainbow of 
text and images. Business owners soon realized how 
effective these colorful beacons were for attracting customers. And unlike a light bulb, a neon sign has 
no incandescent filaments to burn out, and can shine continuously for 40 years 
before the gas depletes. By the 1930s, neon signs were lighting 
up storefronts all over the world. Because of the glass tubes' 
fragile nature, it usually wasn't feasible to ship 
them over long distances. Instead, most neon signs were created by 
local neon shops and then installed nearby. Signs with humor, personality, and 
intricate designs proliferated, no two exactly alike. But by the end of World War II, plastics had become widely 
available and inexpensive, and plastic signs supplanted neon 
as messengers of modernity. Many towns removed neon signs they 
viewed as old-fashioned. Today, neon sign production is only 
a fraction of what it was at its peak, but the craft of tube bending lives 
on relatively unchanged. New creations hand-crafted 
by local artisans join survivors from the heyday of neon, hiding in plain sight in city streets 
around the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why did neon signs become less popular?
Options: A. Their gas leaked poison, B. Glass became outlawed in the 1950s, C. Cheap plastic signs replaced them, D. People got bored of seeing gorgeous, handmade light sculptures
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is credited with developing techniques to capture and make neon gas glow? Options: A. Thomas Edison, B. Georges Claude, C. Nikola Tesla, D. Albert Einstein Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary obstacle to making lighted signs out of neon gas? Options: A. Capturing the gas, B. Making the gas glow, C. Both capturing and making the gas glow, D. None of the above Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the process of removing impurities from the inside of a glass tube called? Options: A. Liquefying, B. Separating, C. Ionizing, D. Pumping Correct Option: D
Question 4: What happens when a neon sign is turned on? Options: A. The glass tube breaks, B. The neon atoms' electrons accelerate and break free of their orbits, C. The sign turns off, D. The sign remains unchanged Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the primary difference between a neon sign and a light bulb? Options: A. The color of the light, B. The type of gas used, C. The lifespan of the sign, D. The incandescent filaments used Correct Option: D
Question 6: What happened to neon sign production after the 1930s? Options: A. It increased significantly, B. It remained the same, C. It decreased significantly, D. It became obsolete Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the primary reason why neon signs were not feasible to ship over long distances? Options: A. The gas used was too expensive, B. The glass tubes were too fragile, C. The signs were too heavy, D. The signs were too large Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the craft of tube bending? Options: A. The process of creating neon signs, B. The process of removing impurities from glass tubes, C. The process of shipping neon signs, D. The process of creating intricate designs for neon signs Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the primary advantage of using neon signs over other types of signs? Options: A. They are more energy-efficient, B. They are more durable, C. They can shine continuously for 40 years, D. They are more expensive Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the significance of neon signs in modern society? Options: A. They are a relic of the past, B. They are a symbol of modernity, C. They are a form of art, D. They are a form of entertainment Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6: What happened to neon sign production after the 1930s? Options: A. It increased significantly, B. It remained the same, C. It decreased significantly, D. It became obsolete Correct Option: C.

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ because it addresses the decline of neon signs, which is the main topic of the ground truth MCQ. Although the options and wording are not identical, the intent and content of the two questions are closely related.

However, an even more similar question can be found by re-examining the generated MCQs. A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that specifically mentions the replacement of neon signs with another material, as stated in the ground truth MCQ.

Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. Nevertheless, the closest match in terms of question intent and content would be Question 6.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 6

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
One of the top chefs from Pasta Palace has been kidnapped by operatives 
from Burger Bazaar hoping to learn the location of their 
secret sauce recipe. Little do they know that a third party— Sausage Saloon— has sent you to take advantage 
of the situation. As their top spy, your skills range from 
infiltration and subterfuge, to safecracking and reading faces 
for signs of deception. You’ve tracked the captors to where 
they’re holding the chef prisoner. From your hiding spot, you can see him 
on the other side of the glass, while in front of you an interrogator 
wearing headphones speaks into a microphone. “We already know the recipe is on the 
13th floor of the bank vault, in a safe deposit box numbered between 
13 and 1300. Now tell us… Is the number less than 500?” You can’t hear the chef’s answer, 
but you can see that he’s lying. The interrogator, however, falls for it. He follows up by asking, 
“Is it a perfect square?” Again you can’t hear the answer 
but can tell the chef is lying, while the interrogator takes 
him at his word. He then asks, “Is it a perfect cube?” This time the chef answers truthfully. The interrogator thinks 
for a minute and says, “Good. Now if you just tell me whether 
or not the number’s second digit is a one, we’ll be done here.” But as the chef starts to answer, the interrogator stands up, 
blocking your view. Within moments he rushes out of the room, announcing that he’s got the answer and 
is sending agents to retrieve the recipe. You know that the Burger Bazaar people 
have the wrong box number. But can you figure out the right one 
and retrieve the recipe yourself? Pause the video to figure it 
out for yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The key here is to work backwards. We don’t know what the chef answers 
to the final question or whether he answers truthfully. But we do know that by the time 
the interrogator asks it, he’s narrowed the options 
down to two numbers– one where the second digit is 1, 
and one where it isn’t. Our goal, then, is to find answers to the 
previous questions that lead to just two possibilities. Of the three constraints offered, the one that narrows our options the most 
is if the number is a perfect cube. That leaves us with only eight answers 
between 13 and 1300. So let’s assume the answer to the 
third question was a truthful YES. Now, let’s look at the second question. If the chef answered YES to the number 
being a perfect square, it would narrow the interrogator’s options
to just 64 and 729– the only numbers in our range that are 
both a square and a cube. But neither of these has a 1 
as the second digit. So the given answer to the second question
must’ve been NO. And that also means we can eliminate these
two squares from the interrogator's list, leaving only six numbers. Now for the first question, 
which allows us to divide this list. If the chef answered YES to the number 
being less than 500, we’d have four options, which is too many. But a NO leaves us with two numbers 
greater than 500, one of which does have 
a 1 as its second digit. We don’t know which of these numbers 
the interrogator thinks is correct. But that doesn’t matter– remember, his conclusion 
was based on lies. You, on the other hand, are now in a 
position to reconstruct the truth. First, the chef said the number was 
greater than 500 but lied, meaning it’s actually less than 500. Second, the chef said it wasn’t a 
perfect square but lied again, meaning the number is indeed a square. And finally, he truthfully confirmed 
that it was also a cube. And as we’ve already seen, the only number under 500 that’s 
both a square and a cube is 64. You find the secret recipe and are gone 
before anyone’s the wiser. Corporate espionage is not an easy game— but sometimes, that’s just 
how the sausage is made.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why don’t you know what actual answers the chef gives?
Options: A. You can’t see him, B. You can’t hear him, C. He’s prevented from answering
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the chef who was kidnapped by operatives from Burger Bazaar? Options: A. The Pasta Palace chef, B. The Sausage Saloon chef, C. The Burger Bazaar chef, D. The Top Chef Correct Option: A
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the location of the secret sauce recipe? Options: A. The 13th floor of the bank vault, B. The safe deposit box, C. Between 13 and 1300, D. In the Pasta Palace kitchen Correct Option: A
Question 3: What skill does the narrator possess as the top spy? Options: A. Infiltration and subterfuge, B. Safecracking and reading faces for signs of deception, C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why was the interrogator able to narrow down the options to two numbers by the time he asked the final question? Options: A. Because the chef answered truthfully to the second question, B. Because the chef lied to the second question, C. Because the chef answered truthfully to the first question, D. Because the chef lied to the first question Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the key to solving the problem in the transcript? Options: A. To work forwards, B. To work backwards, C. To ignore the chef's answers, D. To focus on the interrogator's questions Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the only number under 500 that is both a square and a cube, according to the transcript? Options: A. 64, B. 729, C. 16, D. 36 Correct Option: A
Question 7: What does the narrator conclude about the interrogator's conclusion? Options: A. It was based on the truth, B. It was based on lies, C. It was based on incomplete information, D. It was based on irrelevant information Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the narrator's goal in the problem? Options: A. To retrieve the recipe, B. To find the correct box number, C. To uncover the secret sauce recipe, D. To solve the puzzle Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the result of the narrator's efforts? Options: A. The narrator fails to retrieve the recipe, B. The narrator succeeds in retrieving the recipe, C. The narrator is caught by the interrogator, D. The narrator is unable to solve the puzzle Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the tone of the narrator at the end of the transcript? Options: A. Serious and professional, B. Humorous and lighthearted, C. Sarcastic and critical, D. Uncertain and hesitant Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks why the narrator doesn't know what actual answers the chef gives, and the correct option is that the narrator can't hear the chef.

A somewhat related generated MCQ is Question 3, which asks about the skills the narrator possesses as the top spy, including reading faces for signs of deception. However, this question does not directly address the issue of not knowing the chef's answers.

If I had to choose a generated MCQ that is closest to the ground truth MCQ, I would suggest Question 3, but with a note that it is not a direct match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3 (with a note that it is not a direct match)

However, it would be more accurate to say that none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ, and a new generated MCQ should be created to match the ground truth MCQ.

Here is an example of a new generated MCQ that matches the ground truth MCQ:

Question: Why doesn't the narrator know what the chef answers to the interrogator's questions?
Options: A. The narrator can't see the chef, B. The narrator can't hear the chef, C. The chef is prevented from answering
Correct Option: B

him at his word. He then asks, “Is it a perfect cube?” This time the chef answers truthfully. The interrogator thinks 
for a minute and says, “Good. Now if you just tell me whether 
or not the number’s second digit is a one, we’ll be done here.” But as the chef starts to answer, the interrogator stands up, 
blocking your view. Within moments he rushes out of the room, announcing that he’s got the answer and 
is sending agents to retrieve the recipe. You know that the Burger Bazaar people 
have the wrong box number. But can you figure out the right one 
and retrieve the recipe yourself? Pause the video to figure it 
out for yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The key here is to work backwards. We don’t know what the chef answers 
to the final question or whether he answers truthfully. But we do know that by the time 
the interrogator asks it, he’s narrowed the options 
down to two numbers– one where the second digit is 1, 
and one where it isn’t. Our goal, then, is to find answers to the 
previous questions that lead to just two possibilities. Of the three constraints offered, the one that narrows our options the most 
is if the number is a perfect cube. That leaves us with only eight answers 
between 13 and 1300. So let’s assume the answer to the 
third question was a truthful YES. Now, let’s look at the second question. If the chef answered YES to the number 
being a perfect square, it would narrow the interrogator’s options
to just 64 and 729– the only numbers in our range that are 
both a square and a cube. But neither of these has a 1 
as the second digit. So the given answer to the second question
must’ve been NO. And that also means we can eliminate these
two squares from the interrogator's list, leaving only six numbers. Now for the first question, 
which allows us to divide this list. If the chef answered YES to the number 
being less than 500, we’d have four options, which is too many. But a NO leaves us with two numbers 
greater than 500, one of which does have 
a 1 as its second digit. We don’t know which of these numbers 
the interrogator thinks is correct. But that doesn’t matter– remember, his conclusion 
was based on lies. You, on the other hand, are now in a 
position to reconstruct the truth. First, the chef said the number was 
greater than 500 but lied, meaning it’s actually less than 500. Second, the chef said it wasn’t a 
perfect square but lied again, meaning the number is indeed a square. And finally, he truthfully confirmed 
that it was also a cube. And as we’ve already seen, the only number under 500 that’s 
both a square and a cube is 64. You find the secret recipe and are gone 
before anyone’s the wiser. Corporate espionage is not an easy game— but sometimes, that’s just 
how the sausage is made.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What number box does the interrogator think the recipe is in?
Options: A. 64, B. 512, C. We don’t know
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:

Because the chef lied to the first question Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
One of the top chefs from Pasta Palace has been kidnapped by operatives 
from Burger Bazaar hoping to learn the location of their 
secret sauce recipe. Little do they know that a third party— Sausage Saloon— has sent you to take advantage 
of the situation. As their top spy, your skills range from 
infiltration and subterfuge, to safecracking and reading faces 
for signs of deception. You’ve tracked the captors to where 
they’re holding the chef prisoner. From your hiding spot, you can see him 
on the other side of the glass, while in front of you an interrogator 
wearing headphones speaks into a microphone. “We already know the recipe is on the 
13th floor of the bank vault, in a safe deposit box numbered between 
13 and 1300. Now tell us… Is the number less than 500?” You can’t hear the chef’s answer, 
but you can see that he’s lying. The interrogator, however, falls for it. He follows up by asking, 
“Is it a perfect square?” Again you can’t hear the answer 
but can tell the chef is lying, while the interrogator takes 
him at his word. He then asks, “Is it a perfect cube?” This time the chef answers truthfully. The interrogator thinks 
for a minute and says, “Good. Now if you just tell me whether 
or not the number’s second digit is a one, we’ll be done here.” But as the chef starts to answer, the interrogator stands up, 
blocking your view. Within moments he rushes out of the room, announcing that he’s got the answer and 
is sending agents to retrieve the recipe. You know that the Burger Bazaar people 
have the wrong box number. But can you figure out the right one 
and retrieve the recipe yourself? Pause the video to figure it 
out for yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The key here is to work backwards. We don’t know what the chef answers 
to the final question or whether he answers truthfully. But we do know that by the time 
the interrogator asks it, he’s narrowed the options 
down to two numbers– one where the second digit is 1, 
and one where it isn’t. Our goal, then, is to find answers to the 
previous questions that lead to just two possibilities. Of the three constraints offered, the one that narrows our options the most 
is if the number is a perfect cube. That leaves us with only eight answers 
between 13 and 1300. So let’s assume the answer to the 
third question was a truthful YES. Now, let’s look at the second question. If the chef answered YES to the number 
being a perfect square, it would narrow the interrogator’s options
to just 64 and 729– the only numbers in our range that are 
both a square and a cube. But neither of these has a 1 
as the second digit. So the given answer to the second question
must’ve been NO. And that also means we can eliminate these
two squares from the interrogator's list, leaving only six numbers. Now for the first question, 
which allows us to divide this list. If the chef answered YES to the number 
being less than 500, we’d have four options, which is too many. But a NO leaves us with two numbers 
greater than 500, one of which does have 
a 1 as its second digit. We don’t know which of these numbers 
the interrogator thinks is correct. But that doesn’t matter– remember, his conclusion 
was based on lies. You, on the other hand, are now in a

how the sausage is made.
